markups: Many games describe situations in alternate realities. When the differences between these realities and the real world are created by introducing fantastical or supernatural agents or by letting unrealistic events occur, this is referred to as <style="CurrentLink">Alien Space Bats</style> from a use to describe the implausibility of alternate histories.
For more information, see the Wikipedia entry for the concept.

Note: This pattern is mainly a means for gaining freedom in designing the diegesis and narration in a game. However, since this can provide a freedom in what gameplay is possible also it is described as a gameplay design pattern in the collection.

The role-playing game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Call%20of%20Cthulhu">Call of Cthulhu</link></style> takes place in an alternate version of the world where incomprehensible intelligences, psychic time travelling races, and chthonian entities trapped under the ocean all threaten mankind's sanity and existence.

The background story of the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Doom%20series">Doom series</link></style> is that a catastrophic malfunction during a teleport experiment of Deimos opens the gate to hell.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Command%20&%20Conquer:%20Red%20Alert">Command & Conquer: Red Alert</link></style> uses a time-travelling Albert Einstein to sets up a game where Nazi Germany never existed and a larger Soviet Union battles a united Western Europe in the 1950s.

<style="CurrentLink">Alien Space Bats</style> are ways of creating <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alternate%20Reality">Alternate Realities</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> by changing aspects of the real world rather depicting them as fictional ones created from purely out of whole cloth. The pattern can be used either before gameplay starts or during gameplay. Both may be used created through <style="Link"><link="big-dumb-objects">Big Dumb Objects</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style>, but introducing <style="CurrentLink">Alien Space Bats</style> during gameplay can motivate the introduction of new <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style>, or the <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style> of new <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> as appropriate due to the nature of the <style="CurrentLink">Alien Space Bats</style>. These new game elements or abilities can easily be used to differentiate <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>.
<style="CurrentLink">Alien Space Bats</style> is a diegetic pattern.

<style="CurrentLink">Alien Space Bats</style> are typically introduced as early as possible in games to avoid players having <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style> which may ruin their expectations of a game's theme. This typically means before gameplay, for example through <style="Link"><link="summary-updates">Summary Updates</link></style> or the commercial information accompanying the game.

<style="CurrentLink">Alien Space Bats</style> is a pattern used to attempt to have <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> that are <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alternate%20Realities">Alternate Realities</link></style> due to having supernatural or improbable events or agents introduced. Given their nature, they may however cause breaks in the <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> if not also the likely effects of what is introduced is applied on the diegesis, the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style>, and the gameplay possible within it.

When applied during gameplay, <style="CurrentLink">Alien Space Bats</style> are most often <style="Link"><link="ultra-powerful-events">Ultra-Powerful Events</link></style> that can activate new types of <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style> and make <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> different from each other. This in turn can be used to provide <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style> throughout the game.

Quite naturally, the introduction of <style="CurrentLink">Alien Space Bats</style> during gameplay will likely be a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprise</link></style> that unfold <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style>. Even if <style="CurrentLink">Alien Space Bats</style> could be improvised during gameplay by <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style>, they are most often created as part of <style="Link"><link="summary-updates">Summary Updates</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>. This since it would be difficult for <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> to pull off without being perceived as making arbitrary use of their power, and thereby breaking the <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>.
